intro: Silene papillifolia, commonly known as the papillate catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its delicate, pinkish-purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has hairy stems and leaves, which give it its common name, and it typically grows in rocky or sandy soils. Silene papillifolia is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, known for its showy flowers and often succulent foliage. It is often found in alpine or subalpine environments, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions.
